The process by which certain organisms, typically inhabiting water environments, create underground passageways or structures to escape harsh above-surface conditions, such as prolonged droughts, and maintain their aquatic connection and humidity.

A prolonged period of significantly reduced water availability, characterized by a scarcity of moisture that forces organisms to adapt and employ survival strategies, such as burrowing into deeper, more humid environments, to remain hydrated and viable.

The ability of an organism to endure the prolonged exposure to a dry environment by exploiting a refuge of moisture and oxygen, allowing it to survive until more favorable conditions return.
